smell_analysis.justification: No empty diagrams were found. The PDF shows labeled diagrams across pages 1-19 with visible elements or structured content.

No explicit case was visible where a use case oval is not associated with any actor on the use case diagrams on pages 2 and 3. The overview list on page 1 is a package/overview style listing and is excluded by the rule note.

No two or more use cases were clearly shown to describe the same activity and be associated with the same actor on pages 2 or 3. The naming appears distinct and no explicit actor-sharing duplication is unambiguously visible.

In the package-style overview on page 1, no repeated primary element names within the same package are explicitly visible. Repeated classifier-type text such as 'Klassifikaatori tüüp' on pages 7-8 appears to be tool metadata and is excluded by the clarification.

No explicit denormalized redundant columns storing the same data value across tables without a foreign key connection are clearly shown in the database diagrams on pages 14-19. Shared generic column names like 'nimetus' or standard identifiers are not sufficient to trigger this rule.

Use case names on page 2 ('Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Vaata ...') and page 3 ('Registreeri auto', 'Lõpeta auto', 'Muuda ...', 'Aktiveeri auto', 'Unusta auto') consistently start with verbs, so no inconsistent form is clearly visible.

On the state diagram 'Auto seisundidiagramm' (page 9), no state is explicitly shown as unreachable based on the visible content. Without an unambiguous missing incoming path, this rule is not triggered.

On the activity diagram 'Auto lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm' (page 4), no action is explicitly shown as unreachable. The flow appears to include decisions and repeated paths, with no clear isolated action.

Class relationships shown on pages 5-13 include visible multiplicities such as '1', '0..*', and '0..1'. Database diagrams on pages 14-19 use FK-style notation, which is exempt. No UML-style relationship lacking multiplicity at both ends is explicitly visible.

No single eligible diagram clearly displays 10 or more central elements. The use case diagrams show about 4 (page 2) and about 7 (page 3) use cases; the state diagram shows about 5 states (page 9); and the larger database/class diagrams appear below the threshold based on visible elements. Packages and overview elements on page 1 are excluded.

No class or table is explicitly shown with 6 or more distinct visible relationship lines on any single class or database diagram page. The parsed content indicates typical few associations/FKs per element, and no clear hub with 6+ separate drawn lines is unambiguously visible.

The PDF text does not provide explicit visual evidence that any pair of related elements is placed at a distance more than twice the average distance on a diagram. Without clear, unambiguous layout indication, this rule is not triggered.

Use case names on pages 2-3 appear to start with active verbs. Activity diagram labels on page 4 include actions like 'Vaata', 'Otsi', 'Vali', 'Lõpeta', which also begin with verbs. No explicit non-verb-starting action or use case is clearly visible.
No class, table, attribute, or use case name of 3 or fewer characters is clearly visible. Common elements such as 'Isik', 'Auto', 'Riik', and longer attribute/column names exceed this threshold.

Entity class names visible across class diagrams (pages 5-13) such as 'Isik', 'Töötaja', 'Klient', 'Kasutajakonto', and 'Auto' start with uppercase letters and appear singular. No explicit lowercase-starting or plural entity class name is shown.

Attribute and column names visible in class and database diagrams (pages 6, 11-12, 14-19) appear to start with lowercase letters (e.g., 'e_meil', 'eesnimi', 'isikukood', 'auto_kood'). No explicit uppercase-starting attribute/column name is visible.

Database table names shown in the database diagrams (pages 14-19) appear singular (e.g., 'Isik', 'Kasutajakonto', 'Klient', 'Auto', 'Riik', 'Auto_mark'). No explicit plural table name that violates the rule is visible.

No class, table, or attribute names visibly use type-indicating prefixes like 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'str'. Constraint/index prefixes such as 'PK_', 'FK_', 'pfK_', or 'IXFK_' appear in database notation and are explicitly allowed.
